transcript: - Tech News, it's the story of us. And our eventual replacement by sentient vacuums. - [Man] This sucks! - They deserve it, they work hard. Microsoft was found guilty in 2001 for artificially boosting Internet Explorer using its monopoly power. But now, 20 years later, the company is trying the same thing, with Edge. The latest build of Windows 11 breaks the functionality of a widely used tool called EdgeDeflector, used to mitigate Microsoft's annoying practice of making every web link in a built-in Windows feature open in Edge, even if your default browser is set to something else. Thankfully, developer Robert Maehl, has created a new tool called MSEdgeRedirect, that works around Microsoft's workaround that broke the first workaround. - [Man] Counter-countermeasures! - Whoosh! So users can stay one step ahead of Microsoft's desperate attempts to please, please use Edge, we even made it Chrome, it's just Chrome now, just use it, please. I guess they're not worried about antitrust because that lawsuit was about Internet Explorer. This is Edge, it's completely non-overlapping. - [Man] Stop Edge-ing us! - I'm getting Edge-ed. Gamers were excited yesterday when Rockstar launched the highly anticipated Grand Theft Auto trilogy: Definitive Edition, only to have their excitement turned to horror, as the PC version suffered from graphical glitches, major issues with the rockstar launcher app, and annoying online check-in requirements that made the game unplayable when the servers went offline. - [Man] That's video games, baby. - (laughs) These are from, like, the PS1? Gotta check in, we gotta know, how are you doing? Do you like the game? Rockstar has now pulled the game from sale on PC until they can fix the multiple problems. Although, the trilogy is still available on consoles. Apparently Rockstar has a history of screwing up the launch of remastered versions of its games. So you'd think they'd take the time to iron things out for this one. But maybe the launch itself has the same kind of tongue-in-cheek commentary on how much game launches suck sometimes. Be very on brand. No, no, no, no, no. I punched a sex worker in game to make a statement. You don't get it. - [Man] You didn't pick up her cash. (laughs) - So? Points? And following intense community backlash, Discord CEO, Jason Citron, sounds delicious, - [Man] Lemon-y! - has done the old walk-back after indicating his company was getting onboard the NFT train. Oh no! It all started earlier this week when Citron replied to a tweet from a crypto investor with an image of a Discord build featuring integration with a couple of crypto wallet apps. Then, the Discord community exploded, threatening to cancel nitro subscriptions to avoid encouraging pyramid schemes that "destroy the environment." Do they mean Ponzi schemes? - [Man] That's different actually. - You gotta get your schemes right. - [Man] That's a different scheme. - I know. Check out Investopedia. A couple of days later, Citron tweeted that his original image showed an internal concept that Discord has no plans to ship. And for now they're focused on protecting users from spam, scams, and fraud. The holy trinity. Evil. So Discord users don't have to worry. You're supposed to grab the handle, not the (disgruntled noise) but Made In wants everyone to be able to make restaurant quality food at home. So they source the finest materials and partner with renowned experts to make premium kitchen tools available directly to you, without the markup. Their cookware distributes heat evenly and can easily go from the stove-top to the oven. Plus they got 40,000 five-star reviews and offer a lifetime guarantee. So go to MadeInCookware.com/TechLinked, or click the link in the description, for 15% off your first order. Chef! (chuckles) I know you can do it. Billions of years ago, Quick Bits emerged from the primordial soup. A defense lawyer for Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who killed two people during riots last summer, made a strange argument during the trial this week, that pinching to zoom in on an iPad, shouldn't be allowed because iPads, quote "have artificial intelligence in them that allow things to be viewed through three dimensions and logarithms." - [Man] Ahhh - Those dang old logarithms. - [Man] High school math (indistinct) - 3D ones too! The judge asked the prosecution to prove that zooming in doesn't insert pixels in there and alter the image, which to be fair, it kind of does, but it just, there's just so many, - [Man] The judge knows from looking at a lot of shops in his day. - Speaking of superfluous pixels, Google accidentally pushed a nearly two gigabyte update to pixel phones running Android 12 this week, that was completely unnecessary because the update was the Android 12 build they were already running. Google has now resolved the issue and should probably get to work pushing updates to that lawyer's brain because what? I still can't, what do you think like the iPad AI is going to add in? And support for game mods, just like Steam. Unfortunately the whole app only opens as a tab in Microsoft Edge, so there's still some work to do. - [Man] Stop Edge-ing us! The device is a custom modded iPhone 10 built by robotics engineering student Ken Pillonel, who warned potential buyers that they shouldn't try to use the phone as an actual phone because doing basically anything with it might break it. - [Man] This phone has one life to it.
